educational_objective: Diagnose macroglossia associated with immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis.
question_text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for changes in his tongue. He also reports increased bruising.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is immunoglobulin light-chain (AL) amyloidosis (Option C). In primary (systemic) AL amyloidosis, amyloid deposits in multiple organs, including the tongue. The presence of macroglossia strongly suggests AL amyloidosis. Skin manifestations are present in 30% to 40% of patients and include generalized waxy appearance; easy bruising with minor pressure (pinch purpura); violaceous discoloration around the eyes (“raccoon eyes”); yellow waxy papules and plaques, especially in a periorbital location; and dystrophic nails.
